attributes.alt: Book cover for Baby On Board: How Animals Carry Their Young by Marianne Berkes. The cover shows an otter holding a baby otter as it sleeps.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
How do some animal parents carry their babies?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Understand and use a growing number of prepositions; Respond to instructional language.
Focus attention (self-regulation); Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Understand differences between living and nonliving things.
Help children use prepositions and complete sentences to talk about animal families.
Guide children to talk about how different animals take care of their young.
How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?
What animals and their babies do you see in this book?
What animal can you pretend to be? How does that animal care for its babies?
Look at the pictures of animal families. How  many babies does each animal family have?
What is your favorite animal? Can you draw that animal and its babies?
What materials can you use to build an animal parent and baby?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you use blocks to make a place for a baby animal to sleep?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Baby On Board: How Animals Carry Their Young by Marianne Berkes. The cover shows an otter holding a baby otter as it sleeps.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to practice the Mind Builder.
Focus attention (self-regulation); Develop working memory to  solve problems and accomplish goals.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Understand differences between living and nonliving things.
Help children recall details from the book to answer questions about animal families.
Encourage children to pose their own questions about animal families to show curiosity.
How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?
Can you show an animal that is taking care of its baby?
Can you act like a mother otter who is transporting her pup?
Can you show me an animal that has three babies?
Has a parent transported you somewhere like school or the park? Can you draw or write about it?
Can you draw your favorite animal taking care of its baby?
Can you sound out the word
? What letter sound do you hear at the start of the word baby?
Can you use blocks to show how an opossum mother transports her babies?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make a Connection and introduce vocabulary
How are animal parents and human parents the same?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Focus attention (self-regulation); Develop working memory to  solve problems and accomplish goals.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Understand differences between living and nonliving things.
Help children make connections between how human parents and animal parents care for their children.
Help children talk about how different animals care for their babies.
How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?
Can you name two books that are about how animals take care of their babies?
How do you think a mother dog cares for her puppy? Show me.
How many babies will the animal have if she has one more baby?
How do human parents care for  their children? Can you write or draw about it?
How are animal parents and human parents the same? Write or draw an animal and human parent taking care of their babies.

The mother manatee remains close to her calf. Can you show what that means using blocks?

attributes.alt:
A chart titled The Chicks Say, "Pio, Pio, Pio" shows four images of a hen and its chicks.
The top left image shows each of the three chicks saying "Pio"to the hen. The top right image shows the hen offering the chicks food. The bottom left image shows the hen cuddling with the chicks. The bottom right image shows the hen in the henhouse and the chicks asking for food.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:   The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio”

attributes.alt:
A chart titled The Chicks Say, "Pio, Pio, Pio" shows four images of a hen and its chicks.
The top left image shows each of the three chicks saying "Pio"to the hen. The top right image shows the hen offering the chicks food. The bottom left image shows the hen cuddling with the chicks. The bottom right image shows the hen in the henhouse and the chicks asking for food.

elements.text: Invite children to act out scenes from
Challenge children to sort picture cards in “Shelter” and “Not a Shelter” groups.
How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?
Is the animal in the book doing a good job at caring for its babies? How can you tell?
If you were a hen, where would you hide your chicks to keep them safe? Why is that a good hiding place?
Can you put the animal families in order from smallest to  biggest?
Why do you think the hen in The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio” is a good mother? Can you write about it?
Can you make a finger puppet of a chick?
What letter sound do you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you use blocks to make a place for chicks to sleep? Why is that a good place for them?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Baby On Board: How Animals Carry Their Young by Marianne Berkes. The cover shows an otter holding a baby otter as it sleeps.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out animals from the book and to introduce vocabulary
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Focus attention (self-regulation); Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
“How does your favorite animal take care of its babies?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?
If you wrote a book about animal families, what animals would you put in it?
Pretend to be an elephant  mother. What would an elephant mother do?
If we had a class pet, like a rabbit, how would you take care of it?
Can you write a story about an alligator family? What would they do?
Can you create a kangaroo with a pouch for a joey? What materials do you need?
What sound does a lion make? What letter sounds do you hear when you make that sound?
Can you use blocks to build a place for a penguin dad to keep his egg warm, so he doesn’t have to balance it on his feet?
